pullRequest.title: Concurrent inserts
pullRequest.bodyText:
Detailed description:

Added PgCopy class to insert data into postgres using COPY
Updated SqlEntityListener to use PgCopy instead of prepared statements except for entities
Renamed t_file_data, t_record_files, t_contract_result, t_livehashes, account_balance tables
Renamed columns needed for CSVSchema to work
Maintained batching insert logic
Utilized Caffeine cache to optimize on entity id inserts
Utilized concurrent threads for each tables inserts/selects whether PgCopy or prepared statement

DataGenerator:

Now that SqlEntityListener uses COPY, a lot of code in the data-generator can be removed and many uses of PostgresCSVDomainWriter can be replaced by SqlEntityListener. In fact, this opens up the path to test raw insert performance of SqlEntityListener directly using data-generator.
For the renaming inserts (entities and account balance), use PgCopy too. Added domains for them. Can't use Entities since some columns don't have matching names to fields. Similarly, AccountBalance pojo is not reusable.
Remove manage_constraints_and_indexes.sql. It's purpose was to make initial and repeated loading of data from csv files faster. Since we don't have a/b perf testing, there is no reloading of data. In fact, it'd be easier to use something like the following which is what I've been using in my testing recently.


Load initial data
Backup base db: create database mirror_node_db_base with template mirror_node
Run load/query tests (A)
Drop mirror_node --> reload from 'mirror_node_db_base' --> Migrate if needed.
Run load/query test (B)
Initial load - we don't have foreign keys anymore (constraints part).As for the 'indexes' part, COPY updates indexes in an optimized way.

Which issue(s) this PR fixes:
Fixes #779
Fixes #780
Special notes for your reviewer:
Checklist

 Documentation added
 Tests updated

nodes.bodyText: You should expose this ms duration as a metric for elastic. i.e duration to copy for each table
nit: remove or uncomment as needed
nit: same comment on line 108. I think it's the flush that actually causes the writing to db no?
q: Why the need to create this extra domain class in datagenarator instead of using com.hedera.mirror.importer.domain.AccountBalance?

nodes.bodyText: q: shouldn't we at least have an error log highlighting something went wrong?
You shouldn't need to specify this as Spring Boot uses the Jackson BOM which should pull the version for this automatically.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -36,6 +37,11 @@
     </dependencyManagement>
 
     <dependencies>
+        <dependency>
+            <groupId>com.fasterxml.jackson.dataformat</groupId>
+            <artifactId>jackson-dataformat-csv</artifactId>
+            <version>${jackson-dataformat-csv.version}</version>

nodes.bodyText: Use writeValueAsString() as it's more efficient and cleaner.

Why do we need to store the connection and copymanager and manually close? It's not like we're using transactions anymore between the various tables so they could each use a separate connection (or same, point is I don't think it matters anymore they're the same).
We may want to add the buffer size and make the buffer size a property
Would prefer shorter insertEntityId for this and custom method since it's not like we'll have an insertEntityIdDoSomethingElseOnConflict in the future.

We should consider keeping the batching we had previously but adapting it for pgcopy. Reasons are:
a) To avoid having to load the entire file into memory + keeping all domain objects from file in memory + keeping a csv representation of objects in memory
b) Reducing end to end latency for an individual transaction
We could even keep the default batch size at Integer.MAX_VALUE for now effectively keeping the current functionality but having the option to tweak it to see it's effect on memory and latency during performance testing I think is important.

nodes.bodyText: You can't store this. It's the same effect as the last approach. If the connection goes down this copymanager will not reconnect. Just get it dynamically each time. The connection pool will make it efficient.
What do you mean? It's just a buffer, it doesn't vary. The real bytes within the buffer vary but not the size of the buffer.
You just changed it from base64 encoded to hex. gRPC API is expecting base64
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -50,10 +50,10 @@ void toJson() throws Exception {
                 "\"chunk_num\":1," +
                 "\"chunk_total\":2," +
                 "\"consensus_timestamp\":1594401417000000000," +
-                "\"message\":\"AQID\"," +
+                "\"message\":\"\\\\x010203\"," +

nodes.bodyText: We shouldn't have two stopwatches to record csv generation. Should move csv metric into buildCsv
batchCount please
This should be a HashSet with the other recommended changes
Shouldn't log error twice

I don't think this logic is right. If the database is down it will get added to the cache before the insert and then never get inserted unless the app is restarted. This code should simply entityIds.add(entityId). The cache update should be in executeBatch

You're not specifying which CacheManager. The primary CacheManager will expire entries after 5m, which is not what we want. You would need to create and specify a CacheManager with @Qualifier that does not expire and has no max size (or a really large size).
ByteArrayToHexSerializer to clarify target encoding

nodes.bodyText: Looks like this can be removed?

This annotation and ByteArrayBase64Converter  should be removed. We don't need to convert byte[] to base64 for JPA as we store raw bytes into the bytea type field. If that data is somehow getting stored as base64 encoded bytes that is very wrong.

Technically this is not a cache but a CacheManager which can generate many caches. I wouldn't consider it a session either. Would prefer a more generic name like String NEVER_EXPIRE_LARGE = cacheManagerNeverExpireLarge to allow for reuse.

These metric names are too long. Prometheus will usually add stuff to the end like _total_seconds making them even longer. I don't think the intent is to match them to the package name like it is with properties. We definitely haven't been doing so in the past. Also would be good to have a non-pgcopy specific insert metric in case we switch to repository or something else later. Suggest hedera.mirror.parse.insert and hedera.mirror.parse.csv.
Shouldn't log error twice
We already track csv + insert times separately and don't need to track them combined. We can just use metric queries to sum them together if need be.
Formatted wrong. Not sure what number you're going for. Min should allow lower like 1. Also need to update docs.
Any idea why this is changing? Usually that indicates a bug with the refactoring
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -513,7 +513,7 @@ void cryptoTransferWithPersistence() throws Exception {
         assertAll(
                 () -> assertEquals(1, transactionRepository.count())
                 , () -> assertEquals(5, entityRepository.count())
-                , () -> assertEquals(6, cryptoTransferRepository.count())
+                , () -> assertEquals(5, cryptoTransferRepository.count())

nodes.bodyText: I'm not sure this Qualifier translates to the generated constructor. Have you verified it's not using the primary cachemanager?
Only entityIds should be a HashSet. Everything else should be an ArrayList. The default equals/hashCode implemented by Lombok will cause issues with sets.
Using the Dependency Inversion Principle we should use Collection as the declaration interface for all these entities and not depend upon concrete implementations.
We don't need this metric if we have the per table metric. Metrics can be queried either with or without the tag to show specific or all tables.

Since you manually get connection for pg_notify and turn off auto commit, you will need to close it and rollback appropriately. Or you can look into moving pg_notify to topicMessageRepository.notify(TopicMessage).
Remove and re-throw
The risk is here we continually re-send notifications if a parsing error, but since we filter for dupes on grpc guess that's ok.
